headline: New NZ Parliament Advances Growth-Focused Tax and Regulatory Reforms as Bills Pass Third Readings
summary: Parliament wrapped a marathon day of debate with the third readings of the Taxation (Annual Rates for 2024-25, Emergency Response, and Remedial Measures) Bill and a package of Regulatory Systems bills aimed at streamlining MBIE operations, expanding infrastructure investment, and reforming immigration and work systems. The government defended a pro-growth agenda, while opposition and Green MPs raised concerns about equity, treaty obligations, and civil liberties. With urgency measures and amendments moving through, lawmakers signalled a busy legislative push into the autumn session.

topicSummaries.topic: Taxation Bill Third Reading: Final-Year Fees-Free, $Crypto Framework + IRD/TEC Data-Sharing
topicSummaries.content: The Taxation (Annual Rates for 2024-25, Emergency Response, and Remedial Measures) Bill reached its third reading, following a lengthy committee process and a ministerial amendment paper that added provisions on moving from the first-year to final-year fees-free for tertiary students. The government framed the package as essential for a skilled workforce, including data-sharing between the Inland Revenue Department and the Tertiary Education Commission to determine learner eligibility and entitlements, and measures to enact a crypto-asset framework. Critics argued the package risks a structural debt bias and questioned whether the changes will deliver real gains for students and public services, pointing to concerns about Treaty obligations and net benefits. The bill was passed with amendments to Part 4, and the government signalled ongoing remedial measures in future tax bills.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon SIMON WATTS (Minister of Revenue)
keyExchanges.quote: Well, I'm very proud to be part of a Government that is all about going for growth and making it easier to do business.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon MEGAN WOODS (Labour—Wigram)
keyExchanges.quote: There is a structural deficit in our tax system; that is caused because there is a giant, gaping hole in the tax system.

topicSummaries.topic: NZ Infrastructure Investment Summit: Global Investment, PPP Opportunities, and New Projects
topicSummaries.content: The Government highlighted the NZ Infrastructure Investment Summit in Auckland, which drew more than 100 global investors and construction firms to discuss the country’s infrastructure vision and pipeline. Announcements included investable opportunities such as the Christchurch Men's Prison and the Northland Expressway, plus market soundings for toll concessions on roads and a second Auckland harbour crossing. Positive feedback from international firms and local industry groups underscored a renewed confidence in New Zealand’s project pipeline, with offices and partnerships reportedly set to anchor private capital in the coming years. Ministers framed the summit as a catalyst for growth, job creation, and regional development.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon CHRIS BISHOP (Minister for Infrastructure)
keyExchanges.quote: Earlier this month, the Prime Minister and I hosted the New Zealand Infrastructure Investment Summit in Auckland, which was attended by over 100 world-leading investors and construction companies.

keyExchanges.speaker: Dana Kirkpatrick
keyExchanges.quote: Plenary... is opening an office here in New Zealand. They've committed to bidding for public-private partnerships over the next five years, partnering with local suppliers to ensure local businesses benefit.

topicSummaries.topic: Resource Management Act Reform: Two New Acts, Standardised Zones, and Growth-Driven Planning
topicSummaries.content: The Government outlined its replacement for the Resource Management Act with two new Acts, aiming for a more liberal planning system anchored in private property rights. Cabinet has endorsed a package that features standardised zoning, streamlined plans, spatial planning, and a reduced regulatory drag to enable growth while maintaining environmental safeguards. Proponents point to Castalia’s estimated 45% savings in process costs and argue a culture shift away from frequent objections will unblock development across sectors such as aquaculture and urban building. Critics highlight concerns about consultation with iwi and treaty settlements, potential takeovers of local decision-making, and the risk of regulatory overreach. The debate signalled a planned first-reading in coming weeks and ongoing policy work on implementation.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon CHRIS BISHOP (Minister for RMA Reform)
keyExchanges.quote: Yesterday, the Government announced that we have agreed on the shape of the Government's replacement legislation to a far more liberal planning system with less red tape premised on the enjoyment of property rights.

keyExchanges.speaker: Simon Court
keyExchanges.quote: How is the Government going to protect property owners from busybodies seeking to impose restrictions on their enjoyment of their private property rights?

topicSummaries.topic: Regulatory Systems Bills Third Reading: Immigration, Workforce, and Economic Development – Cross-Party Support with Scrutiny
topicSummaries.content: Two omnibus MBIE-focused bills – Regulatory Systems (Immigration and Workforce) Amendment Bill and Regulatory Systems (Economic Development) Amendment Bill – were given third readings after broad cross-party consideration. MPs welcomed minor but important updates to multiple Acts, emphasising clearer regulatory provisions, better information sharing, and improved governance of regulatory agencies. The Green and ACT benches highlighted practical improvements such as tighter regulation of immigration advisers and streamlined compliance, while Labour emphasised worker protections and social considerations. The bills were praised for their clarity and efficiency gains, even as some MPs reserved judgement about broader policy implications related to housing, health, and the economy.

keyExchanges.speaker: Dr LAWRENCE XU-NAN (Green)
keyExchanges.quote: One of the areas—there are a lot of quality of life improvements, like I mentioned. It amends seven Acts...

keyExchanges.speaker: Parmjeet PARMAR (ACT)
keyExchanges.quote: The ACT Party supports these bills.

topicSummaries.topic: Drug Driving Bill Third Reading: Road Safety Framework with Roadside Testing and Civil-Liberties Considerations
topicSummaries.content: The Land Transport (Drug Driving) Amendment Bill passed its third reading after intense scrutiny. The regime introduces roadside oral fluid screening with a confirmatory laboratory test, plus a mandatory 12-hour stand-down for those testing positive. Supporters flagged the urgent need to tackle drug-impaired driving, citing death and injury statistics, while opponents raised concerns about potential impacts on civil liberties, particularly around detention times and the treatment of prescription medications. A statutory five-year review was established to assess effectiveness, technology, and fairness, with ongoing debates about the limits of enforcement and the balance between public safety and individual rights.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon CHRIS BISHOP (Minister of Transport)
keyExchanges.quote: This is Parliament's third attempt in about three or four years at introducing oral fluid testing for drugs at the roadside.

keyExchanges.speaker: TANGI UTIKERE (Labour—Palmerston North)
keyExchanges.quote: This is a piece of legislation that Labour supported at first reading; was very constructive, through the select committee process; and supported at second reading. We did have some issues that weren't resolved at the committee stage, but, despite that, we come to third reading and as a party we will be supporting this bill this evening.

conclusion: As Parliament closes a busy day of readings and urgent motions, the government’s pro-growth tax and regulatory package moves forward, even as opposition and Green MPs press for greater consideration of equity, treaty obligations, and civil liberties; the path ahead will include further scrutiny, implementation planning, and five-year reviews to adapt to a changing policy and economic landscape.
